thread.title: ScienceShot: Animals That Live Without Oxygen  - ScienceNOW

message:
Most parasites have very complex life cyles, and intestinal worms do not spend their entire life in an intestine.  The example that comes to mind for me is Ascaris, which is quite possibly the most well researched nematode on earth.  The adult worms do live in the intestine, and they are  anaerobes, but they still have mitochondria, and their embryos must have molecular oxygen to grow and develop.  The fertilized eggs need time outside of the body to develop and become infectious.  They hatch after a host has swallowed the and the Juveniles need so much oxygen, that they migrate from the intestines through the circulatory sytem and into the lungs where they grow.  When they are mature they migrate out of the lungs and into the mouth where they can then get swallowed.  Once they are back in the intestines, they can be anaerobic again.   
With all of that said, you should see in the article that it noted finding various stages of the Loricifera life cycle in the anaerobic environment.  Which suggested that it can spend it's entire life without O2.  That is a key difference.

thread.title: No More Black Holes? - ScienceNOW

message: Black holes don't exist, because it takes forever for a star to collapse to a point with zero volume and infinite density from our point of view as external observers. It's nice math from the point of view of the star itself, but it's not the reality in our frame of reference. The simple fact is that General Relativity breaks down in black holes. Singularity, i.e. an arbitary mass in a zero volume is nonsense. Forever lasting collapse into a black hole or matter forever approaching the event horizon as viewed by external observers is nonsense. Hawking has combined quantum mechanics with GR, while they do not agree at all. GR does not apply on small scale where QM applies, while QM does not apply on large scale where GR applies.

thread.title: A Very Memorable Trip - ScienceNOW

message:
In reading this article, it becomes apparent why the use of psilocybin has for so many centuries been deeply rooted in so many cultures. The drug was widely used by college students and age-peers in the 1960s and 1970s in North America, of course. But its use is a significant part of oral and writen histories of various Native American tribes and/or enclaves, with echoes reaching back to Asian and African cultures, as well. The ingestion of psilocybin was often a part of religious ceremonies and was chronicled with an unfortunate mixture of truth and imaginative fiction in the cult-like books of a writer with the pseudonym Carlos Castenadas, in his "Don Juan" stories of Hopi Indian practices. 

The myths surrounding psilocybin have reached absurd levels in some cases. I have met a young (at the time) man who owned photographs of the mushroom sliced at different angles - in one, there was the suggestion of a kneeling, riant figure. This man was convinced, therefore, that the Lord Jesus Christ was actually a myth built around the mushroom and its spiritualistic effects.

thread.title: Do Brain-Training Programs Work? - ScienceNOW

message:
The interpretation of this study is astonishingly over-reaching.  The BBC researchers designed their own cognitive stimulation program, applied it at a very low intensity in healthy young people, and then saw no effect on cognitive function.  To then claim that their data shows that "computerized mental workouts don't boost mental skills" is akin to saying "sugar doesn't help with a headache, and sugar and aspirin are both molecules, so aspirin must not help with headaches either."  This is an elementary logical fallacy.

The only conclusion from the BBC study is that very limited amounts of everyday cognitive stimulation does not improve cognitive function.  This is an interesting conclusion, and the study should have reported it as such.

Henry Mahncke
I am a researcher at Posit Science, where I design and test cognitive training programs.

thread.title: Is the National Science Foundation Taking Enough 'Risks'? - ScienceInsider

message: The inherent riskiness of funding high-stakes, high-reward research proposals goes beyond the fiscal risk taken by the NSF and other federal funding agencies. Risky projects also affect the researchers willing to take on such research projects, as they are also potentially throwing their careers into a game of scientific Russian roulette. Particularly for non-tenured academic scientists, risky projects can make or break a career. However, such potential discoveries are often the most fruitful for scientific advancements, and it is encouraging to see efforts being made to lessen the hesitation of academics towards undertaking high-stakes projects. After all, agencies such as the NSF should be encouraging promising scientists and their projects, lest we all suffer the consequences of missing out on their latent scientific contributions.

thread.title: Calm Sun Is Bringing a Chill to England - ScienceNOW

message:
"Actually doing the math" is not the issue.  Climate models take into account ONLY direct solar insolation, NOT the effects of solar activity on indirect effects such as this article is addressing, as well as the increasingly researched area of the effect of solar activity on El Nino - La Nina patterns (as a paper from the Nat'l Center for Atmospheric Research pointed out) as well as the quantity of cosmic rays reaching earth's atmosphere which affects cloud condensation nuclei and concomitant global cloud cover.  Feedbacks are the issue here, not direct solar insolation which your point addresses.

Also, CO2 (when "actually doing the math") has only very limited effects on global temperature.  The models depend on the secondary effects of water vapor to reach their alarmist temperature increase conclusions.  

CO2 also has a logarithmic contribution to temperature--meaning that it's contribution to the greenhouse effect is largest in the lower end of its addition to the atmosphere (the great majority of heating from CO2 is already in play).  At some point, no matter how much CO2 you add to the atmosphere, it can add only miniscule theoretical rises of temperature.  If it were simply a matter of the math of direct CO2 accumulation, we'd never have had the global cooling from the 1940s to the 70s or during the recent past decade.  Natural variability can obviously overwhelm any effect by CO2.

message: Pardon me for jumping in here, but I must. "Theory" is one of the most misused words in the language -- including by scientists -- to the point where even the dictionaries are having to adjust. The word you mean to use is "hypothesis." thread.title: Iceland’s Volcano Proving Tough to Predict - ScienceNOW

message: I have no formal training in vulcanology, but read about it a little recently.  When this volcano first started to erupt, I was a little surprised that we weren't seeing a phreatomagmatic event - the heat of the lava coming into contact with the snow and ice causing explosive thermal contraction, and a large plinian ash column and many lahars.  It seems like we now have had/are experiencing this kind of activity at Eyjafjallajokull.  I guess it makes sense that a change in magma type would cause this.  But there's no mention of a basalt-type magma here, and I thought (from my brief readings) that that was the sort of magma likely to fragment into dangerous angular lapilli and ash?  I would have also thought that once the ice and snow has run off from the area around the vent, there would be less explosive activity?  Are there additional vents?  Does a dike connect Eyjafjallajokull and Katla?  Are we now seeing activity based on pressure more than explosive thermal contraction?  I'd be interested to hear a vulcanologist's take on the situation.

thread.title: From the Archives: Iceland's Doomsday Scenario? - ScienceNOW

message:
Gas turbine - jet engines spin at incredibly high speeds; the stainless steel 'buckets' are shaped a very special way, and so I can imagine ultra high temperatures in such turbines combined with glassy particles of soot and ash, could lead to a coating that would cause long term damage, or erosion of bearings etc. Over 30 years ago, I performed some inspections of such parts in steam turbines as a quality control inspector.
Considering other damage to windscreens etc., and the relatively soft aluminum surfaces - I think that modern aircraft are not all that robust. 
On the other hand, I do not doubt heavy or reactive metals coming out of volcanoes would be harmful.

The following morning I have the answer when I awake...

then turn on the other side and dream using emotions...  

As a young man I had 2 premonitions in dreams, and told others before they came true,

When the accidents described actually occurred, tragedies were averted in both cases...

You mentally construct 2 separate math calculations in your mind...  
They can be simple but not too simple...

thread.title: Does Our Universe Live Inside a Wormhole? - ScienceNOW

message: Yes, but mathematical law does not translate to physical law. It depends on what is meant by "proven". Tenets of pure mathematics can be proven because they are absolutes- mathematical law- but these can only model the real world, not define it. Using your example, thermodynamics cannot be mathematically proven, only modeled, because it is a physical principle. The closest you can get to scientific "proof" is through experimentation, but even then it cannot be verified under all possible circumstances, so it remains a physical model (albeit a very good one), not a true physical law. It's great when pure math and real data tightly agree as it suggests the mathematical model is accurate- quantum mechanics has done very well in this regard. But a mathematically-based idea is not particularly useful in the physical world until it has an experimental or at least observational basis. That is why some things like string theory or faster-than-light theories do not at present fulfill the definition of theory- they are mathematical models only but without direct physical evidence, so they aren't yet, as you said, "functional" models- they are indeed mathematical hypotheses about the physical world. Which gets to my original point- calling every new idea in physics that is so far based only on calculation (including this one) a scientific "theory" is not only misleading, but feeds the misunderstandings about the meaning of the term among the general public- i.e. "it's only a theory".

thread.title: Mass of the Common Quark Finally Nailed Down - ScienceNOW

message: I showed in Florida Scientist Vol 68, #3 (2005) (see my website for a copy) that there is a very simple way of determining from the PDG data tables that the proper mass of the up quark which occurs in the simpler baryons such as protons and neutrons is 1.914 MeV (rounded) with the similarly identified down quark at 5.11 MeV.  These masses are toward the lower ends of the PDG uncertainties.  But this cannot account alone for the stair-step of masses in the N particle Series for instance, or any other of the baryon series.  These series arise because each quark also has a less basic (but precise) alternate mass toward the upper end of the PDG uncertainties, not an isomer.  And these higher masses arise one at a time in place of the lower ones, with the heaviest N particle having only the higher masses at the top step of the stairs.  All are covered by a simple power/exponential law derived from the PDG tables.  At each step of the N or Delta, etc., series of heavier quark substitution options there is a group of the particles with a lightest group leader and typically two isomers of slightly greater mass.  All very systematic, and without having to rely on an infinity of virtuals.----- It will be interesting to see what account the PDG takes of the Davies group's new calculations

thread.title: Calm Sun Is Bringing a Chill to England - ScienceNOW

message:
Your idea sounds good until you ask anyone who actually knows how to do the math to figure out how much cooling or warming can possibly be caused by a given increase in solar activity. The increase in solar activity would have to have been 3-10 times greater to explain the increase in average temperatures. 
Below I posted a link to one paper that assumed the maximum possible increase allowed by measures of past solar activity. I could have posted many more but all the papers/research on this seem to say the sun can be in it alone.

http://www.agu.org/journals/ja/ja0305/2002JA009753/

Average temperatures have only been deceasing since 2006. I do not feel that four years is enough data to be confident that it is part of a trend. I would wait for the measurements of the next decade before making overconfident remarks.

Physicists have been doing calculations on how much warming or cooling may result from changes in atmospheric gas compositions for several decades. The numbers of what to expect from changes in CO2 concentrations have become more precise but still remain significant in spite of all the research. CO2 is not off the hook for anything yet nor is it the only greenhouse gas. I would give it another 30 years of temperature measurements and advancements in climate models.

message: It's interesting to note that Duesberg, the "AIDS scientist," has published little or no original research on HIV and AIDS. Instead, he has authored many review articles in which sources and statistics appear to be selected to match his hypothesis that HIV does not cause AIDS. His "Medical Hypotheses" is not the first example. In other articles, for example his 2003 review in the "Journal of Bioscience," he makes very questionable statements about the work of other scientists, statements some would consider outright misrepresentation. On the side, Duesberg has made it his business to advise individual HIV-positive people to avoid medical treatment. The late Christine Maggiore sought out Duesberg's advice before becoming an AIDS denialist activist...and foregoing treatment, including during pregnancy. She passed the infection to her daughter; both are now dead. Also dead are hundreds of thousands in South Africa, who were denied antiretrovirals under the regime of Thabo Mbeki. He began to question HIV as the cause of AIDS after reading Duesberg's website, and he invited Duesberg to advise him on AIDS policy. The victims of this scientific irresponsibility, sadly, never received a letter of reprimand, and they were dismissed from this life, not from a comfortable academic position.

thread.title: Exclusive: AIDS Scientist Investigated for Misconduct After Complaint - ScienceInsider

message:
Martin Delaney's letter to NAS, from July 31, 1997. 

Dr. Bruce Alberts
President, National Academy of Sciences
2101 Constitution Ave., NW
Washington, DC 20418

July 31, 1997

Dear Dr. Alberts,

I am writing as the head of a nationally known AIDS organization and as a representative of a larger group of AIDS service providers. I am also a member of the NIAID Council and a member of the former Medicine Roundtable on the Developments of Drugs and Vaccines for AIDS. I am writing today to seek your attention and advice on a matter which has come to trouble almost all of us working in the AIDS service field.

Our concern is the continuing public campaign of Peter Duesberg to convince the public, people at risk of HIV infection, and people already infected that they are in no danger from this virus, that AIDS is solely a behavioral disease, and that current treatments for the disease and recreational drug abuse are in fact the cause of the disease. I have followed this debate for more than a decade and have yet to see any meaningful scientific evidence that supports these views. Instead, over the years I've seen a rapid accumulation of evidence that conclusively disproves his viewpoint. His views have long ceased to be a topic of serious discussion within the scientific community. Having lost the debate with his peers, he has taken his campaign to the public and directly to the people most vulnerable- young and poorly informed people struggling with HIV infection. He fans a natural inclination toward denial on the part of such people, giving them a seemingly legitimate way to ignore a positive HIV antibody test, to cast aside the difficult behavioral changes associated with safe sex, and to forego the complex challenge of multi-drug combination therapy. Obviously, such a deceptively attractive package will find a ready audience.

No one opposing his views wishes to discourage his academic freedom, nor do I see evidence that this has been done in any way. Though he claims his views on AIDS are responsible for the loss of NIH grants, it is far more likely that this is due to his lack of contribution and publication in his own field over the last decade. The scientific community has shown unprecedented tolerance for his behavior, as well-meaning people hoped that the airing of his views would lead him to see his errors. Such is not the case. Just as the right of free speech doesn't sanction the person who yells "fire" in a crowded theater, neither does academic freedom provide blanket protection for irresponsible behavior by scientists which adversely affects the public health.

Perhaps most troubling is the degree to which his current campaign has come to flaunt the scientific method. His disregard for accuracy and integrity in the scientific process is amply demonstrated in the lengthy review published in 1995 in Science Magazine by Jon Cohen. In this and in Duesbergs own recent book, even the most junior of trained observers can see how he chooses to overlook all data which contradicts his conclusions, while misstating and distorting the data on several aspects of the disease. I had the misfortune of debating Professor Duesberg and his cohort Kary Mullis together in 1995 and found both strangely ignorant of some of the simplest principles of drug Developments and clinical research.

A most recent example of how badly he has come to flaunt the values of science can be found in the attached material. I have included here an ad, placed personally by Professor Duesberg, announcing a public presentation of his views at the Metropolitan Community Church, a gay community facility in San Francisco. The audience is hardly the scientific community. Instead, it is aimed at enticing another generation of younger gay men- in whom new HIV infections are already running rampant- into seeing things his way. The most remarkable aspect of this is the effort he has taken to make the program look like an official program of the University of California at Berkeley, right down to the use of the University Seal. It also features his 1986 appointment to the NAS. It most certainly is not a university function. Moreover, the entire text of the ad is deceptive, disguised to look like an ad for one of the many community forums held about the new therapies, research advances, and viral load. There isn't a hint anywhere as to what the real agenda is, or how he will do his best to discourage the use of the new drugs and diagnostic measures which have given so much hope and new life to so many people. He will be there to try to convince an unwitting and otherwise uninformed audience that there is serious scientific support for his contrarian view and that all those who hold other views are somehow puppets of the pharmaceutical industry and a conspiratorial research establishment. Undoubtedly, he will succeed with some of those present, and no doubt hasten their deaths. In these days when AIDS therapy has shown such great promise, it is difficult to distinguish his actions from those of a mass murderer.

I am writing to you as the chief executive of the National Academy of Sciences because Professor Duesberg is a member of your distinguished body, whose mission is to serve the public interest. His actions, I believe, are an affront to everything the NAS stands for. They mock your Academy's commitment to the scientific method and to the principle that scientists should fight their battles in a peer setting, not by public relation efforts in the public. As members of the public aggrieved by his actions, we call upon the National Academy of Sciences to raise the question of whether he is fit for continued membership in your group. I would like to propose a few possible topics for debate by the NAS:

- Given a thorough review of his scientific and public behavior in the AIDS epidemic, should Peter Duesberg remain a member in good standing of the NAS?
- Should the NAS issue a public statement, perhaps reaffirming his academic freedom, but condemning his efforts to sway the public rather than his peers?
- Should the NAS broker a settlement with Professor Duesberg which would, minimally, prohibit him from further promotion of his potentially harmful views to the public until he presents convincing evidence to the NAS that the common view of HIV and AIDS are in error?

I would like to set up a meeting between yourself and several representatives of AIDS service organizations to discuss this matter in greater detail. I will call your office to seek an appointment.

Sincerely,

Martin Delaney Founding Director, Project Inform

Organizational Endorsements:

Act-up Golden Gate, Oakland, Ca.
AIDS Action Committee, Boston, Ma.
APLA/AIDS Project Los Angeles
AIDS Research Alliance, LA
AIDS Service Center, Pasadena, Ca.
AIDS Treatment Initiatives, Atlanta, Ga
Being Alive, LA
Center for AIDS Prevention Studies, UCSF AIDS Research Institute
CRIA/Community Initiative on AIDS, NYC
Critical Path AIDS Project, Phil., PA
Denver Buyers Club
FAIR
Florida AIDS Action Council, Miami
Kraus Medical Group, LA
Multicultural AIDS Coalition, Boston, Ma.
Project Inform
PWA Coalition Colorado
Research Sanctuary, LA
"Resolute: Dedicated to Surviving HIV/AIDS", Denver
Robert Smith Medical Group, San Diego
San Francisco AIDS Foundation
Test Positive Aware Network, Chicago
United foundation for AIDS, Miami
Women Alive, LA

thread.title: Exclusive: AIDS Scientist Investigated for Misconduct After Complaint - ScienceInsider

message:
It's about time. Here's an example of Duesberg (along with co-authors Claus Koehnlein and David Rasnick) deliberately misquoting an NEJM paper in an article they published in 2003:

http://www.duesberg.com/papers/chemical-bases.html

"the evidence for 'declining morbidity and mortality' is only based on uncontrolled survey studies that investigated how long HIV-positive, clinically healthy subjects, but mostly from AIDS risk groups, survived on various anti-HIV drugs. The largest and most influential of these surveys was conducted by Palella et al (1998) who investigated in 1998 1255 anti-HIV drug-treated 'patients, each of which had at least one CD4+ count below 100' from nine clinics in the US. However, all of these 'patients' were 'nonhospitalized', AIDS-free subjects. 'Patients with a diagnosis of cytomegalovirus retinitis or M. aviarum complex disease before study entry or during the first 30 days of follow-up and patients with active P. carinii pneumonia at the beginning of follow-up were excluded.' A similar survey investigated in 2001 1219 anti-HIV drug-treated Canadian HIV-positives with less than 200 CD4+ cells, of which 87% were AIDS-free (Hogg et al 2001). Neither of these studies mentions drug-free controls."

The NEJM paper by Frank Pallela that is being misquoted focused on people with advanced illness (less than 100 CD4 T cells). The full text is available online: http://content.nejm.org/cgi/content/full/338/13/853

The data shows the highest mortality was among people that never took antiretrovirals, the lowest among people on triple combinations (see table 1). 

What Duesberg does to try and explain away the data is pretend that the participants in the Palella study were healthy before starting antiretrovirals. This is not the case, all had <100 CD4 T cells and many had previous opportunistic infections. Duesberg et al have altered the quote from the Palella paper to make it seem like people with opportunistic infections were excluded. But this is what the quote says in the actual paper:

"Patients with a diagnosis of cytomegalovirus retinitis or M. avium complex disease before study entry or during the first 30 days of follow-up and patients with active P. carinii pneumonia at the beginning of follow-up were excluded from the analyses of the incidence of that opportunistic infection."

In other words, they weren't excluded from the study, they just weren't counted as having developed that particular opportunistic infection during the study, if it was pre-existing or developed during he first 30 days. Because the sentence, in its original form, is also an acknowledgement that people entered the study with a history of opportunistic infections and not just low CD4 counts - i.e. not "asymptomatic" or "AIDS free" as Duesberg is claiming - Duesberg accomplishes a double deception just by inserting a period after the word "excluded." 

The fact that the Palella paper reports data on people who never took antiretrovirals also contradicts Duesberg's statement that "Neither of these studies mentions drug-free controls."

The late Martin Delaney of Project Inform also wrote a letter to the NAS many years ago demanding that they review Duesberg's membership; as far as I know he never received a response. I'll post a copy if I can find it.

thread.title: Saturn's Strange Hexagon Recreated in the Lab - ScienceNOW

message: You are both right in that the Danish experiments were compared with Saturn's hexagon at the time, even though none of the critical dimensionless parameters of this experiment matched those of Saturn itself even within an order of magnitude. That is what is different about our experiment - the Rossby number and basic instability mechanism in the experiment are plausible for conditions on Saturn, unlike the Danish experiments which merely reproduced polygonal patterns. We make no claim to be the first to produce polygons in fluids - there are plenty of examples in the literature already going back more than 20 years. What is different here is plausible dynamical similarity with Saturn (albeit only partial) - which we suggest is certainly not 'bad science'!

We see time different from our galaxy because it takes us about 200 million years to make a complete orbit. The same orbit  may be like a second from the point of view of the Milky Way. This is due to time compression, relative size and conscious frequency. Perception of time is relative, like the conscious differences between humans and humming birds or flies. That why its so hard to catch a fly because it sees time differently relative to you. 

It’s almost like we are swimming in a sea of time rather than space. If something has any dimension it has to exist in the dimension of time. Everything is evolving vibrations of energies. To evolve it needs the dimension of time to allow cause and effect to take order. Time is the one dimension that is entangled with all other dimensions. Almost as if time was fundamental to everything. 

Time is primary to space in Space-Time. I even began calling it Time-Space. Here’s why. Time gives things order and 3 dimensional space is like a blank canvas for cause and effect move around. (If Tim-Space was a particle, time would be the nucleus and space would be the outer shell.)

 If I drop a baseball, the ball must follow a logical order of decent. It cant leave my hand appear two inches off the ground, then seven inches up, then six inches down then hit the floor. It has to follow a natural evolutionary path and time is the main dimension which permits this. From superposition, the greater of the odds collapses to one possibility and follows the logical path of order. That’s why time flows forward. It is the most efficient way energy can evolve over space. More so, nature can only do things in the most efficient way. That’s why grass does not strain to grow and why light is our event horizon and our speed limit defining our natural boundaries. Nature must choose the path of least resistance. Then my mind began to wonder why would nature use a force as weak as gravity to sculpt the cosmos especially when it needs all this imaginary Dark matter to work. *Plasma is responsible for 99.999% of the visible universe. It is highly conductive and since everything is made out of energy wouldn’t nature use it’s most abundant resource to sculpt the universe. 

If you are trying to solve a problem it is wise to look to nature first and see how deals with the problem. For example if we want to travel among the stars we might try to figure out how to make a filed of some sort around a star ship to make it appear massless to the rest of the universe. But you may run into problems if you want to return to Earth in the same time era as you left. Time on Earth will move faster than relative time on your star ship the closer you get to the speed of light and you may return 300 years in Earth's future.

thread.title: Does Our Universe Live Inside a Wormhole? - ScienceNOW

message:
Is it possible for a universe to be at the center of a black hole?

A black hole is not a hole at all.  It’s relatively spherical.  A sphere that is 3,000 times the mass of our sun but only 10 times the diameter sits at the center of our Milky Way galaxy.  It powers the galaxy the way our sun powers our solar system, just on a much larger scale.  When I began to think of a Black Hole as a sphere and not some kind of drain that matter falls into, I started to see things differently.  Matter was pulled into the center of a sphere, from all directions at once.  The singularity could be thought of as the core of the black hole.  

I began to think of a black hole as a type of star.  What happens to a super massive star?  It’s life ends because gravity wins out.  The core collapses into a black hole.  Black holes grow by consuming gas and dust.  They also grow by  merging with other black holes.  It would make sense then to believe the core of the black hole would also grow.  What would happen to the black hole when and if gravity wins?  What would happen if the core of the black hole collapsed?  

Is it possible that the energy released when the core of a black hole collapses ignites the birth of a new universe?  And that universe exists inside the mother black hole which itself exists in it’s own universe.  When the core collapses a big bang occurs.  A massive sun is destroyed after a supernova.  I believe a black hole survives its supernova.  The new universe will exist and expand from within the mother black hole.  I believe that energy from the baby universe radiates back into the mother universe by means of Hawking radiation.  Hawking radiation might even answer the question of the expanding universe.  Our universe is expanding at an ever increasing rate.  Hawking radiation may be pulling our universe apart.  

A growing singularity within a super massive black hole seems to me very similar to the description of the first moments of our universe.  A perfect medium of infinite mass.  Matter stripped down to it’s most basic elements.  I believe these are one and the same. 

At the instant the core collapses a big bang occurs.  The explosion instantly creates a bubble within the mother black hole.  This bubble could be Guth’s inflationary theory.   

Dark matter may be the outer regions of the mother black hole that completely surrounds the baby universe.  A shell of black hole would have a powerful gravitational pull of its own pulling the baby universe apart.  The baby universe grows within the mother black hole until it has matured and eventually dies.

Dark energy may be the current created by Hawking radiation leaking back into the mother universe.  A universe dying and a black hole evaporating back into space are the same thing, I believe.

message: Actually Joe, I think I do understand it quite well. Your quote of "theories can incorporate facts and laws and tested hypotheses" mentions only tested hypothesis. Without at least one tested hypothesis you do not have a theory. Darwin's hypothesis attempts to extrapolate observations of the natural world as we see it today all the way back in time to the point where there was no life in a world that no one has ever seen much less left a record of. People have attempted and failed to recreate this so called primordial soup condition and attempted to coax life from lifelessness using all kinds of external stimuli that were seen as plausible to exist. This is the basic brick in the hypothesis, and until you can devise an experiment to show reliably and repeatedly by any research facility that life can be caused to occur from lifelessness in some probable scenario, then all you have is a untested hypotheses. Also, to counter your claim that gravity is a theory, I say that gravity is a natural condition that exists whether you understand it or not. If there was a valid theory of gravity then you should be able to manipulate it. Let us all know when you have come up with an anti-gravity device. It will make you rich beyond the wildest dreams of avarice. By the way, I am a practicing Electronics Engineer so I have a pretty good grasp of things that would have been called "magic" only a couple of decades ago. The following link describes the scientific method. Among other things it supports my contention that a tested (proven true) hypothesis precedes an idea being advanced to the status of being a theory. http://www.sciencebuddies.org/science-fair-projects/project_scientific_method.shtml

thread.title: Does Our Universe Live Inside a Wormhole? - ScienceNOW

message: I am unfamiliar with the cited paradox. However, in general, when people start trying to use mathematics to "prove" that something must exist simply because the odds in favor of it are astronomical then I get pretty skeptical. In this case, consider the bombardier beetle. It manufactures two chemicals within its body that explode on contact. It uses these chemicals to spray boiling hot liquid on anything that may attack it with spray nozzles that it can point in almost any direction. Why doesn't the beetle explode itself when these chemicals mix? Why doesn't the beetle get burned by the boiling hot liquid? Everything about the bombardier flies in the face of Darwin's hypothesis. Every part of the bombardier beetle used in this deadly defense mechanism including its explosion proff mixing chamber and its heat resistant makeup HAD to come together all at once. Otherwise the beetle would have blown himself up the first time it mixed those chemicals. Not very likely to get itself very far along an "evolutionary" path if it blows up every time a predator attacks. What do you suppose the odds of all those parts evolving at once are? One scientist who studies those beetles figured the odds were astronomical against it. He went from being a Darwinist to a creationist as his studies of the Bombardier continued. The Bible says that the evidence of the creator are within the things created. The house you build to live in is evidence of a builder. Things simply do not happen by themselves. Otherwise we would be fond of saying things like "Isn't it wonderful that that car just created itself out of nothing just in time for you to start using it?"

message: Actually I do not think either of those fields represent experiments that establish that life evolved from lifelessness which is the basic tenet of evolution. When you take existing life and manipulate it to create a copy or a hybrid all you are establishing is that that existing life-forms can be modified by external stimuli. Not too different from what can be done accidentally with various mutagenic chemicals. You can call it what you want, but I call it adaptation. A simple example can be seen in the faces of abalone divers. Due to the constant exposure to cold water, their body responds by adding a lot of blood vessels especially in the epidermis giving them a very ruddy complexion. Repeated long enough , the offspring of these hardy individuals would likely be born that way. Voila! a new sub-species. Still the ability to add blood vessels in response to repeated exposure to cold water was intrinsic all along. So really no evolution or permanent change occurs.

Astrophysicists  must eventually come to terms with the fact that the Big Bang does not make sense.  Really now, there was a singularity, meaning what, a one of a kind thing? and then suddenly it just exploded?  what caused it to explode? was pressure building up inside it? does that mean there was a time before the big bang, during which pressure built up? And to say our universe comes from another universe, well, that's something of a cop out, because isn't the universe supposed to encompass everything?
Now, you don't have to let go of it yet, because evidently the Big Bang theory still has plenty of legs on it.  It's the most comprehensive  (though far from complete) explanation they've come up with so far (oh excuse me except for the explanation involving the giant bearded man in the white robe who lives in the sky and declared everything into existence) and is stimulating additional thinking.  But eventually you'll have to move on.  We need a better explanation.  It's probably obvious that I am not a professional scientist, but here's what I think:  the Big Bang is like the concept of a Point in geometry.  It doesn't really exist, but by postulating that it does exist, we've come up with a lot of useful ideas that help to explain and measure reality.  So keep at it, but don't get to enamored of it, because eventually that theory is going down!

You don't understand science.   A theory is an operating model - nothing more.  Gravity is a theory.  As is evolution, electromagnetism, nuclear physics, etc.   Theories are upheld by observation and evidence and discredited or replaced with more likely theories as additional insights and evidence are combined.  

You may read more here:
http://wordnetweb.princeton.edu/perl/webwn?s=theory
Theory (a well-substantiated explanation of some aspect of the natural world; an organized system of accepted knowledge that applies in a variety of circumstances to explain a specific set of phenomena) "theories can incorporate facts and laws and tested hypotheses"; "true in fact and theory"

A theory does not pretend to be a Truth or a Fact.  A Theory is a framework to explain things.  A leading theory tends to be that which is shown to be the most likely when subjected to classical logic.

I actually agree, it's not just knowing what scientists think. But we're still not talking about the same thing, I fear, so let me try a different approach.

In Chapter 7 of the Science and Engineering Indicators 2008 (http://www.nsf.gov/statistics/seind08/front/about.htm): "Scientific literacy is the capacity to use scientific knowledge, to identify questions and to draw evidence-based conclusions in order to understand and help make decisions about the natural world and the changes made to it through human activity."

I maintain a person can do the above without *accepting* the theory or denouncing all others. I'm not saying this is common, but nevertheless I see no reason why a person couldn't be a proponent of Creation, and yet have formal mastery of the principles of Evolution. Such a person would have the ability to use scientific knowledge to draw evidence based conclusions about Evolution, and yet for whatever reason may decide to make decisions about the natural world based on Creation.

Or using your question of gravity as an example:

"Gravity is the result of the warping of space-time by mass where bodies follow the shortest path as dictated by this curvature." What about "gravity is a force mediated by a massless (and hypothetical!) elementary particle with spin-2?"  Does your question about relativity require me to categorically denounce the existence of a graviton? If it does then maybe I'll answer "no" because (as far as I know, and admittedly I don't know much) this is still an open question. Oh wait, was the intent of your question simply to confirm I knew relativity is one theory about gravity? Then say so: "General relativity explains gravity as the result of the warping of space-time..." and I'll answer "yes".

We should consider the other big bangs or planetary collision that have occurred before the so-called ultimate big bang that scientist have theorized. There is also an infinite number of universes out there in space. And they were not created either; they were just there. We do not have the capacity to comprehend the dimension that could be used to accurately describe their existence. So, we should indeed leave it that. We will never know or understand everything, we can only do our best to understand our world. In fact, we have done pretty well with our limited resources of science and mathematics.

message: Lee Smolin first put forward this idea many years ago, and excellently expanded upon by Quentin Smith, called "fecund universe" theory. The idea is that a star in another "parent" universe collapsed and created a black hole, where our universe exists around the edge of the disk of the infinitely spiralling and expanding black hole's singularity point. Many black hole's in our universe would potentially have other "baby" universe's at their singularity points, and so on. It would be evolution on the grandest of scales, as universes seed themselves with stars with the ability to propagate more universe's, constantly refining themselves toward the right state of elements and conditions for this to occur. This theory is more appealing to me than our universe's existence inside of a wormhole.

thread.title: No More Black Holes? - ScienceNOW

message:
Firstly, there are no such things as tachyons except in the imagination of people who feel there shouldn't be a limit on speed. If any such thing is found, then many fundamental results of relativity (which is the only theory that tells us anything about black holes anyway) is thrown into chaos.

Secondly, nothing is spewed 'from the top and bottom' of a black hole. High energy matter in the accretion disk surrounding a black hole can be ejected outwards in jets and accelerated by magnetic fields, but certainly not from inside. Tiny black holes can emit thermal radiation, but the microwave background means this can never lead to a net emission for any black hole more than a tenth of a millimetre across.

And white holes... haven't a clue what you're on about. What goes in, stays in. If you throw a billion tons into a black hole, you get a black hole that's a billion tons heavier, and it doesn't come out again. Don't know what you've been reading (or smoking) there, Meiliken... but it does sound fun.

The Galileo affair was a sequence of events, beginning around 1610, during which Galileo Galilei came into conflict with the Catholic Church over his support of Copernican astronomy.[1]

In 1610, Galileo published his Sidereus Nuncius (Starry Messenger), describing the surprising observations that he had made with the new telescope. These and other discoveries exposed major difficulties with the understanding of the heavens that had been held since antiquity, and raised new interest in radical teachings such as the heliocentric theory of Copernicus (published in De revolutionibus orbium coelestium in 1543).

In reaction, many scholars attacked the theory because it seemingly contradicted several passages of Scripture. Galileo's part in the controversies over theology, astronomy, and philosophy culminated in his trial and sentencing in 1633 on a grave suspicion of heresy.

message: That's what it *should* be, but theoretical physicists tend to play fast and loose with that meaning. String "theory", for example, has yet to move beyond a mathematical model because our accelerators aren't fast enough to experimentally test its predictions. Not to mention various faster-than-light "theories". When a physical tenet is largely accepted, it is referred to as a "law", an unfortunate and rather arrogant term used largely due to historical reasons. But this also makes it annoyingly difficult when it comes to explaining what is meant by "theory" of evolution- which is biologically equivalent to a physical law, but sounds weaker just by virtue of how the word is misinterpreted.

thread.title: Evolution, Big Bang Polls Omitted From NSF Report - ScienceInsider

message:
"The universe began with a big explosion" is a terrible statement for the scientifically literate, as far as I am concerned.  Do I agree with the Big Bang theory?  Well, I'd say it's the best theory available that fits the evidence, but would I say it was necessarily a big explosion, like somebody set off a bunch of firecrackers?  Eh, not so much.  The "explosion" was a literal outward progression of matter from an originally highly-condensed state, but I can see where one might consider that differently from an "explosion" of bomb variety.

That being said, there's really no excuse on the evolution front.  The fundamentals of science make it clear what constitutes a valid hypothesis, and there's no experimental (much less rigorously examined and reproducible) evidence for "Intelligent Design"/Creationism.  If you want to believe something or someone set off the Big Bang, well, nobody can disprove you, but it's pretty clear that humanity has physically changed over the past six thousand years alone, much less over the time span before that.  Disagreeing that humanity has been around for more than six thousand years indicates a lack of scientific literacy as well, given the dating methods we have available.  Disagreeing with the accuracy of radioactive isotope dating is basically equivalent to saying the scientific method as we know it just made up whatever it felt like.

thread.title: Evolution, Big Bang Polls Omitted From NSF Report - ScienceInsider

message: You obviously don't understand them, or the evidence for them if you don't find them convincing. At this point evolution as a general explanation for how life changes and adapts is essentially irrefutable. Aside from all the fossilized evidence (where are the dinosaurs in the bible?), experiments with fruit flies, observing adaptation in the wild, decoding the genome, etc... we're now also able to use the principles of evolution to solve highly non-linear optimization problems that have nothing to do with living things. In short, evolution works both as a process and a general explanation for how life changes and adapts. Those who claim otherwise haven't seriously examined the facts, or are too brainwashed to accept them.

thread.title: Does Our Universe Live Inside a Wormhole? - ScienceNOW

message: "Can't be proven to exist" does not mean "it can't exist" or "it doesn't exist". Neutron stars and black holes were believed to be just the theoretical products in the non-realistic world, but now most of the physicists believe they exist. Indeed, the statement "We'd go from 'we don't really know how the big bang started' to 'we don't really know how this wormhole started'. We'd also go from 'dark matter expands the universe' to 'wormhole end points expand the universe'" simply means that we have one more alternative theory explaining the beginning of our universe. Providing alternatives is always the job of theoretical scientists, especially physicists. If the theory itself is not flawed, then why not? That's the true philosophical core of doing science: pursuiting the truth.

message:
"Part of being literate is to both understand and accept scientific constructs."

Literacy is our ability to internally conceptualize something we read in order to understand it. That understanding may lead to acceptance if we BELIEVE it is sound, but understanding is only a logical process - logical processes are faulty when false axioms are assumed (something humans appear highly prone to do).  Acceptance of any matter is by no means necessary to be literate on that matter.

In fact, science as we know has been driven by paradigm shifts - by people who do not accept the common beliefs. Accepting something just because it APPEARS logically sound would be practically suicidal to the scientific community.  It's only when we accept theories HYPOTHETICALLY that there's enough context surrounding them to truly develop them into what may one day be the whole truth.

thread.title: When Pigeons Flock, Who's in Command? - ScienceNOW

message: Have these researchers read Len Fisher's book "The Perfect Swarm, The Science of Complexity in Everyday Life?"  There are three rules that bird flocks, fish schools, bee and locust swarms, and ant trails follow.  1.  Follow the rear end in front of you.  2.  Stay close to the guy next to you.  3.  Don't bump into the guy next to you.  There is no leader in the typical sense of the word.  Any bird with a specific intent becomes a leader.  A bird that is hungry and flys to a known food source is followed by the other birds that have no specific intent.  These researchers may be going over ground already well researched.

thread.title: Does Our Universe Live Inside a Wormhole? - ScienceNOW

message:
Let's see.  1. Wormholes can't be proven to exist.  At all.  Previous theories also requires negative mass to hold them open, which itself is a theory.  An unproven theory holding up an unproven theory is not very stable.  2. I think the problem with the three types of gravity is that we can't reconcile them right now.  Which means one or all of them is fundamentally flawed anyway.  3. Even if this was true, it wouldn't change much of anything.  We'd go from "we don't really know how the big bang started" to "we don't really know how this wormhole started"  We'd also go from "dark matter expands the universe" to "wormhole end points expand the universe".

I'm all for theoretical scientific advancement and explanations in the name of pure knowledge of the cosmos, but this is plain dumb.  Mostly because of point #1.

Once again, we have someone who obviously doesn't know the difference between a regular theory and a scientific theory. Let me clear it up for you.

a regular theory is essencially a hunch, as in "i have a theory that the butler did it"

a scientific theory is, in fact, greater than fact. it is a concept that encompasses a huge amount of facts collected over a long period of time, such as atomic theory, cell theory, and the theory of gravity. the theory of evolution contians facts and figures from the fossil record, microbiology, biochemistry, and indeed many other fields of study.

So before replying to something like this, try to know the terminology before you start spouting out nonsense.

message: I'll only add one thing to this to cure some ignorance.  There is one thing insofar that does escape a black hole and that is tachyons.  The only way something solid could travel through a black hole would be to travel faster than light.  Traveling faster than light would obliterate anything solid due to the sheer gravitational friction, and that's not counting the gravity of a black hole.  To send something solid to FTL flight would require something that can make a static warp bubble or a self contained bubble of gravity.  Gravity that is strong enough to withstand outside gravity.  Something like that doesn't exist with current technology.  Yet.  But if Tachyons can escape a black hole, then other things can as well.  When looked at through a spectroscope, a black hole can be seen spewing out cosmic energy from the top and bottom.  That is what is left afterwards, and is the building blocks of all matter/energy in the universe.  Look up both black holes and white holes and you will see they correllate.  They are what constantly pulls in and expells the energy that creates the universe, a literal cosmic sized recycling center that keeps the universe balanced.  Without a balancing factor, the universe would not be here for it would destroy itself.

thread.title: No More Black Holes? - ScienceNOW

message:
I second this. The general formula of popular science journalism seems to be: Find something that could suggest something earth-shattering; Find some other scientist with half a brain (a whole is too much, none is too little) and ask them what they think; report as if both ideas have even-level credibility.

New math that works pops up all the time, it doesn't mean it is so. When it comes to theoretical physics, which is any kind of physics we can't directly observe, it is all about what theory makes the most accurate predictions with the least complexity. In that order.

A complex theory that makes even the smallest improvement to predictions is the new working model. One that can be made more simple but retain the same level of predictive quality, is the new working model.

The reason that we think of time as fluid is that we are, ourselves, observers. And the math must take that into account and the easiest way to do that is to assume time is fluid. This doesn't mean it is. It just means that the math is more simple if it is. Since it makes the same quality predictions as the HORRIFICALLY complex alternative theories you need to make time progression constant, it is the preferred working model.

It isn't perfect. For example, the 3 body problem. But it does a better job of predicting things like the orbit of Mercury and how much light will bend around the sun than did the model before it.

So, what about this new idea with black holes makes better predictions? Well, assuming all else is even, it fits with how we have always presumed the universe to work. Which is that information, and I mean here the physics concept of information, can't be destroyed. Because if you could make information vanish, our history would vanish. We would not be able to trust any observations, nor even our memories. Black holes have long been thought to break this flow of information. There are a few ways to sort of avoid it, such as Hawking's idea that black holes infuse other universes with that information, and I guess presumably it could one day enter another black hole and re-enter ours? Not sure how that works. There is also the idea that when a black hole would evaporate the caught information would be released. However, if this theory suggests another way to have all the effects of a black hole without the loss of information, then perhaps it is a better model.

We wouldn't know until we could make observations of it. Actually, we may never know, because if black holes make information vanish, we can't really trust what we think we know about them, even when observed.

thread.title: Evolution, Big Bang Polls Omitted From NSF Report - ScienceInsider

message: This isn't quite the same as theories are mental models which people create to organize and generalize the (imperfect) data that is acquired through experiment and obervation of the external world.  Mathematics is a totally abstract concept that does not exist externally, and is by its nature exists entierly within the mind.  Although evolution is supported by the observational evidence, there are some aspects of molecular biology that don't quite fit the evolution theory (at least when it is stated simply).  These require "tweeks" in the theory, much as relativity modified the original laws of motion as stated by Newtonian theory.  In mathemtics, the rules are created and the individual cases of mathematical epxressions are based on the rules. Forinstance, there is more than one system of mathematics (particularly self consistant systems of geometry, although Euclidian is the only form with which most of us are familar).   Tomorrow new data could surface that would cause us to throw out the theor of Evolution -- or gravity or classical thermodynamics (which is only a subset of quantum thermodynamics).  There will never be new "data", however, in any system of mathematics, as these start as purely mental constructs.

Actually, JP, you are wrong. Scale differences are tolerated all the time in perfectly good science and engineering. In fact, without those tolerances, developing new things would be prohibitively expensive and terribly dangerous.

Wind tunnel experiments are carried out on airframes of a size quite different from the eventual experimental and production planes they model. Boat hulls are tested for seaworthiness in warehoused tanks far smaller than any ocean. Etc.

In fact, the fractal nature of reality allows for surprisingly accurate predictions of all sorts of physical systems, from the micro to the macro in scale.

thread.title: Evolution, Big Bang Polls Omitted From NSF Report - ScienceInsider

message:
While I disagree with some of his conclusions, Dr. Bruer is correct in called the questions "very blunt instruments."  However, all "true or false" questions are blunt instruments, especially if you closely consider the questions poised.  If you are averse to blunt instruments, don't use these kinds of questions in surveys.  I would say they are a necessary evil, however, if you want a wide sample of a large population that isn't going to sit still for essay questions. In the full article, Bruer makes the valid point that if the qualifier "According to the theory of evolution..." is inserted before the question, the percentage of "true" responses is much higher.  We should consider whether "scientific literacy" means " I've heard of this theory, and I know what it means," or "I've heard of this theory, and I believe it to be true."  

A big part of the problem is that at one time a survey which showed a large percentage of the population did not believe currently understood scientific theories was taken to be a sign that our educational system was deficient, and we were falling behind other countries in a threatening world. Today there are prominent people who hold that denial of these theories is perfectly consistent with their alternate beliefs, and so view this as a good thing!

thread.title: No More Black Holes? - ScienceNOW

message:
Nobody's saying the Milky Way is a black hole. There's just a fairly large black hole at the centre. And yes, it's expected that every galaxy should have one at the centre (in addition to having a few million normal-sized black holes scattered among its stars).

The other thing about black holes is that all they lead to is obliteration. Even before you arrive at the centre of the black hole, all the particles of your body are stripped apart and completely causally separated. (Causally separated means placed completely and forever out of reach of any possible contact or effect on each other - as if every particle is in a different universe... but they're not.) That's something for anyone with pretty ideas about fractal universes to think about.

Yep, that's the way to handle ignorance - just don't talk about it and don't measure it.

First we stop asking how many people understand that the universe began with an expansion, or that species evolve.  

Next, we can stop asking how many people understand the Earth is billions of years old.

Where will it end?

If our educational system worked, we would be ADDING questions every year, not removing them.  People should not only understand the basics of evolution and cosmology, they should be able to answer questions about the contributions of people like Aristotle, Alhazen or Maxwell.

I simply don't understand this national love affair with ignorance.  We revel in it, glorify it, and wear it like a badge of honor.  If you can't be good at sports or have a lot of money, at least you can claim complete ignorance of science!  Woo hoo!  Be proud!

If someone doesn't understand that species (including humans) evolved, then they are ignorant.  And ignorance is an important thing for us to measure and track and address.

thread.title: No More Black Holes? - ScienceNOW

message: Everyone needs to stop throwing around the term "infinite".  There can be no infinity.  Infinity ruins all physics.  A black hole is not a point in space where gravity grows infinitely strong, it's not infinitely massive, nor infinitely small.  It's strength of pull on another object is based on both their masses and the distance between them.  What happens if one is floating in space and they are drawn by earth gravitational pull.  They fall toward earth at 9.8m/s2, accelerating until reaching terminal velocity.  Same thing would happen in a black hole.  You'd just fall to the core of it's gravity and probably be liquified by the intense heat of friction.  Riddle me this, based on the equation for gravity that gives us 9.8m/s2 here on earth, could there be a black hole with a mass producing a force of gravity of 299,792,458m/s2, the speed of light? Technically, with enough mass and using that equation, yes.  What if it were more than the speed of light?  One law of physics against the other.

thread.title: Evolution, Big Bang Polls Omitted From NSF Report - ScienceInsider

message: All theories to be theories have to be able to be wrong. It is called falsifiability. It does not matter whether it could be wrong or not, it just matters that it is a valid scientific theory and it counts as both valid and important in understanding basic science. Newton's theories are both valid and wrong at the same time. They have been supplanted and expanded by Einstein and others since. Even if Darwinian Evolution is wrong, or rather incomplete in that it does not adequately explain things and in the future a new theory is formulated that does a better job, it does not matter because that is the future and today Darwinian evolution by process of natural selection is the current foundational model for all of the biological sciences. As such it is an extremely important bit of knowledge to have. Maybe if the people that disagreed with the theory so much actually took the time to learn about it they might come up with something better than saying "God did it". But that would take scientific literacy.

thread.title: New Peptide Helps Cancer Drugs Break Into Tumors - ScienceNOW

message:
"Tumors keep drugs at bay in two ways. First, their vessels are not leaky enough to allow drugs inside."

This is a bit misleading as there are many anti-cancer therapies, for example liposomal drugs, that have preferential accumulation in tumor tissue as a result of the increased permeability of tumor vasculature.  This phenomenon is known as the Enhanced Permeability and Retention (EPR) effect, and was reviewed nicely by Maeda et al in the European Journal of Pharmaceutics and Biopharmaceutics in 2008.

thread.title: Pro-Animal-Testing Rally Tomorrow in Los Angeles - ScienceInsider

message:
As DrugMonkey notes, the scientists who are actually doing the work know there's not currently any way around animal experiments for many types of research.  For example, I needed to study the interaction between cells in the bone marrow and a bone tumor.  Because I didn't want to hassle of dealing with animals and also because research review boards require it, I looked long and hard for an alternative way to study the phenomenon, but eventually got as far as I could with culture models.  I wrote up my attempts to find an alternative way of doing the research in my report to the review board.  There's simply no way to model a bone marrow environment in a tumor bearing animal in a culture dish, and then to examine the effect of a drug requires different routes of administration, none of which can be done in vitro.

Believe me, I wouldn't have done the animal research if there was any way I could have gotten around it, and pretty much everyone else felt the same way. It's costly, time consuming, and inconvenient, but I was able to do research that uncovered a new treatment path for an incurable cancer. Was that a justifiable reason?

That's how science works in the real world.

But what if we simplify matters and studies this from a more scientific perspective and say that the person with and without prostheses weigth the same and that we know that the only thing generating force in this case are the thighs (the person with prostheses have no calf muscles and can therefore not run as fast as the healthy person). The prosthese is not as fast as the biological and therefore should they be accepted in shorter laps where the momentum konsevation doesn't give any advantage, like 100meters sprint. But longer laps give prostheses unfair advantages.

thread.title: ScienceShot: Animals That Live Without Oxygen  - ScienceNOW

message:
Gotta love life - where there's a resource, it will adapt to exploit it.

On another tangent, I've often wondered if microorganisms like this may hold the key to cancer.
See, the mitochondria is what processes oxygen, and is also the cellular suicide switch.
Cancer messes with the mitochondria. It needs to, because in order to grow and survive, it needs more oxygen than other cells.

So, what if... we could use some intravenous anaerobic food and quite literally remove all the oxygen a patient breathes, and replace it with nitrogen? Would the cancer die, while the other cells remained alive on their alternate fuel supply?

To some extent we already do this in short bursts. Sprinters store anaerobic fuel. That means its possible.
The only real problem is preventing kidney or liver failure during a forced anaerobic coma.

thread.title: ScienceShot: Animals That Live Without Oxygen  - ScienceNOW

message: Folks - be careful with reading too much into this. It is certainly a great discovery that multicellular organisms are now known which can be anaerobic (this was already known for many unicellular organisms) - especially since the vastly efficient energy harvesting that comes from being aerobic was thought to give rise to complex multicellular life in the first place. So the lifeform gets its energy through other processes, not by respiring oxygen (O2). However - and this is the biggie - it does NOT mean we have knowledge of ANY life that can live without atomic Oxygen (O). Think about it - this anaerobe, all previously known anaerobes, and every other lifeform currently known needs the same basic elements: C H N O P S, because these are critical for the building blocks of life (nucleic acids, proteins, lipids, carbohydrates). This "new" lifeform still uses all those same building blocks and its fundamental chemistry is still exactly the same as every other life form. In this short, this is definitely still exactly "life as we know it". It would be very misleading to think this, or any other anaerobe, "lives without oxygen". Anyway, that wouldn't be a problem on other planets... there is enough molecular oxygen to go around the universe, so this should in no way fuel speculations about outer space life. Again, it's the "structure" of life that is unique on Earth, and all know life, including this new one, follows the same basic structure. If were to find something, for example, that used Silicon instead of Carbon or Sulfur in place of Oxygen, or information storage in something other thand DNA/RNA, or "proteins" made out of something other than amino acids, etc... THAT would be something fundamentally very different, and has yet to be seen.

thread.title: ScienceShot: Animals That Live Without Oxygen  - ScienceNOW

message: The lack of oxygen is the foremost barrier to life in space, but for multicellular animals it would be closely followed by the lack of food. Loricifera are hetereotrophic organisms, meaning they have adapted to feeding upon other organisms. Therefore Lorcifera could not survive in space. Some single cell anaerobes derive energy from abiotic compounds, sunlight, or radiation (as some fungi appear to), so they might be able to survive outside the atmosphere. You must also keep in mind that the wide variety of temperatures encountered would have dramatic effects on enzymatic activity, affecting all forms of life.

thread.title: No More Black Holes? - ScienceNOW

message:
"As Einstein demonstrated in his Theory of General Relativity, a passenger inside a spaceship traveling toward a black hole would feel the ship accelerating, while an outside observer would see the ship slow down"

This is incorrect. The passenger would be in free fall, so wouldn't feel any acceleration - in fact would feel no different to empty space until tidal forces became significant at a few thousand km distance (for a stellar mass black hole), and that would feel altogether different from an acceleration.

Observer outside wouldn't see the ship slow down, they'd see it accelerate into what would seem like an infinite distance into the black hole, getting progressively more red-shifted. If the observer could view events on the ship, or the ship's clock, THAT would appear to slow down.

And this is a prediction from Einstein's theory - I don't think he actually 'demonstrated' it. He didn't put a passenger in a ship and send it into a black hole. That wouldn't be ethical. :)

Matter does take an infinite time to reach the horizon of the existing hole, from the point of view of anyone outside, but it very quickly enters the horizon of the NEW hole ( = old hole + spaceship ), and at that point there's no problem in saying that it becomes part of the hole from the point of view of an external observer. Perhaps there are Planck length ambiguities here, but I doubt our friends in Ohio have any more idea about that than you or I.

I wish science journalists would be honest and state that some scientists have developed a mathematical methodology or model in which black holes cannot form - which is interesting enough - instead of suggesting they've "shown" anything to be the case. These models inevitably have their own assumptions and provisos which may or may not be far-fetched. It's not as if these guys are overturning the standard view of black holes at all.

thread.title: East Coast Winds Would Support a Stable Power Grid - ScienceNOW

message:
100% wind power is possible, but there are a couple of details to consider.  First, the fact that wind power can be produced continuously doesn't mean it can be produced in volumes and at times that are consistent with customer demand.  For that you need storage, which is very expensive.  Second, wind machines produce DC power that has to be passed through an inverter, and that process creates some technical problems that could affect the large existing stock of AC motors.  Third, you'd need a lot of wind turbines.  Finding an acceptable place (or places) to put them might be problematic along the eastern seaboard.  Wind power could also be produced in the midwest and moved to the east coast, but that requires transmission lines that are equally difficult to site.

Bottom line:  like anything else, 100% wind power is possible, but it will be expensive, time-consuming and require lots of infrastructure most folks do not want in their back yards.

I think like many Americans Steve is being "Americentric" in his viewpoint. Other than the Yellow river, most of the lakes you mention are in very dry to extremely dry climates. These areas probably shouldn't have any real populations, maybe 300-400 year ago numbers. And...in that regard Steve makes a good point in that population control is the only real answer. 

Chad and Australia (to use your examples) have climates that have been getting drier and will continue to do so as the climate changes. It all really comes down to how much the regional ecology can support the people living in it. China is ravenous in it's consumption right now. The Yellow river has several damns and irrigates crops throughout the region. Ironically, these same dams also cause the worst (deadliest) flooding in the world. 

While some areas need to look at conserving it's water for future use (places that rely on lakes/reservoirs and have dry environments), and while better irrigation techniques can reduce water loss to the environment, making a big hoopla over the water we use to produce corn is "pushing it" IMO. 

As a side note, Ft Mac uses a lot of water to produce oil from the sands, and much of this water gets polluted.

thread.title: Could Tiny Bubbles Cool the Planet? - ScienceNOW

message:
Please re-read the the article to see the finer points most all posters have missed...the bubbles will be added at a rate of 1 ppm by volume. You'd be hard-pressed to find that single bubble with a microscope, let alone noticing the difference with the naked eye, so don't be thrown by the misleading, frothy, ocean surface photos accompanying the article.  Spread those bubbles over a unit thickness area of one square meter and 99.9999% of the sunlight will miss those 1 ppm bubbles.

Also note, the bubbles are micro-bubbles (specifically ~ 2 microns according to Seitz) that could stay suspended for days because of their size (remember Stokes Law). This process is low cost compared to upending the entire world economy (which will work only if EVERY country goes along with it), completely reversible in a matter of days, and is based on solid scientific concepts. With a nod to William of Ockham, sometimes the simplest solution is the best.

thread.title: Should Social Scientists Help the U.S. Fight Terror? - ScienceInsider

message:
Hmmm? Some time about the sixth grade, I learned that there are about thirteen original ideas.  Mr. Atran seems to have made at least for him a startling discovery. We need social scientists to understand the way of terrorists and non-Napoleanic war tactics. Who knew!!

The notion that the DoD and by implication the rest of the Federal government responsible for our security--DHS, NSA, CIA, FBI--has somehow ignored the need for social scientists and psychologists in an important much less minor role in the war on terrior is (uh) sophomoric. Why the Subcommittee invited this lightweight to testify is hard to understand. Oh!  Maybe Jerry Post from George Washington and say George Everly from Johns Hopkins among a host of others already engaged in fighting terror were busy. 

The service of such professionals continues today. For instance, shortly after 9-11, I was asked by DHS to assemble and manage a 24-7 cadre of academic experts on weapons of mass destruction.  The objective was to help trouble shoot response and communicate the nature of an attack and how the response would be carried out, and why, etc. Early on, in consultation with DHS officials, we concluded that one of if the central issues was to put the human factor up front and center by having social scientists, psychologists, and a full array of other disciplines as a major part of our team--thus the reference to Jerry and George. Even so, some knowledge of DARPA, if only their calls for proposal, might lead, even the most unaware, to suspect that human vagueries would be important.

As I read deeply into this article, I decided to see who Mr. Scott is. At first, I thought I imagined that an error had been made and that maybe he is an adjunct in the Drama Department. Academics embedded with rifles! Soldier-psychologists and sociolologists--you bet.  So while many US citizens, not just academics, may still rail against the wars, particularly IRAQ, the military is quite capable of having soldiers with the technical backgrounds, even PhDs and Post doc-level individuals, amongst their ranks.

Am I angry that our tax dollars are wasted on such pap like this that is camouflaged as expertise.
