thread.title: Why Didn't Early Earth Freeze? The Mystery Deepens - ScienceNOW

message:
It is a strong chunk of "evidence," but I posit that it does not fully constrain the CO2 picture. If validated with further data points gathered in similar formations from relatively modern formations -- or from formations created in intermediate times from the early- and mid-Archean to the Cambrian, the point might be made.  I agree with Kasting.  Basically this is an evidential item, but solar physics suggests the linear luminosity increase [of ~1%/100My] calls for a great many other contributory GHG's.  The evidence for snowball and ice ball Earth era's is very convincing during the most recent last 2Gy, but the Sun is already warm enough to quantify the insolation and correlate it with better atmosheric assessments.  That is, by then Bacteria have put a lot of O in the air. 

Methane, early, has to play a part -- but if the early biogenic battle was between species producing O and CH4 the atmospheric result shows a longer lifetime for the O, so it builds up. The biogenic CH4 production continues to this day.  We need to be thankful it is not a biogenically dominant component in this era.     

Didachus touches on the geothermal balance -- which we know is not an insignificant factor in the first Gy.  Geothermal outflow continues, mantle differentiation still drives tectonics, and at best the story on early atmospheric GHG's is not completed or much constrained by the Nature report.

Right now it [this report] looks like a thumbtack holding a scrap of note pad paper on the bulletin board -- not yet a book on the shelf, or the desktop.  It appears to be good work that needs more lines of different observational physical evidence to flesh it out.  The truth is "out there" even if heavily recycled from it's appearance on the Earth's surface.

Maybe the biological component was more significant, and methane was a larger factor -- in early periods.
Heterogeneous Hadean Hafnium: Evidence of Continental Crust at 4.4 to 4.5 Ga -- also weighs in [http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/full/sci;310/5756/1947?maxtoshow=&hits=10&RESULTFORMAT=&fulltext=Hadean+era&searchid=1&FIRSTINDEX=0&resourcetype=HWCIT]

Ideas of Life also enter:
http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/full/sci;315/5814/937c?maxtoshow=&hits=10&RESULTFORMAT=&fulltext=Hadean+era&searchid=1&FIRSTINDEX=10&resourcetype=HWCIT

For my part, I come away going to Solar Physics for a respite.

The very fact that huge quantities of C are contained in non biogenic rocks as well as the later limestones suggests that early C was bound to O and possibly N in significant quantities -- but this more than 100 times the current airborn or biological quantity of C we know about -- had to reside "somewhere" in the early environment.  To repeat:  Where was the C hiding in the Hadean and Archean -- if not in the atmosphere?

I guess it is fair to say we need a lot more data points, as well as a comparison with even older Rocks  to bolster the small CO2 atmosheric component this work indicates. [? No wonder algae grew so slowly back then, deprived of easy C in the air . . ?] 

For Earth, the Sun turns on at the beginning of the Hadean.  The moon is splashed out within the first 20 - 50 million years.  But the oceans return, and tectonics and differentiation continues throughout the Hadean into the Archean . . . [I like the closer to 20My in the beginning, rather than the 50my -- and where the heck in the Galaxy were the Supernovae of the Sun and Earth's birth -- were we nearer to the Galactic core. . . you know, the galactic geography. . .? ] 

By the time of the Archean, the Sun is about 10% warmer than at main sequence ignition.  So don't wander into the faint Sun as 30% diminished, think of it as only 20% diminished at least.  It was warmer than that 30% suggestion -- so think of it as roughly 80% of now.

In fact, at dim sun ignition [4.567Gya] Venus's water would be pure greenhouse gas and the water/heat death of Venus, inevitable.   Obviously the Earth's Hadean oceans were liquid -- think: they are also liquid in most or much of the Archean. And the Sun warms from then on.  Snowballs and Iceballs occur later, and such planetary episodes are likely all in Earth's Past.

We can still have minor Ice Ages, after humankind are gone, and after what traces of life left on the planet have been able to extract the blip of CO2 we've left -- and which may close the chapter on many current lifeforms.  Geological and biological means of removing our CO2 legacy will possibly return to pre-human balance as soon as 1.5 to 2my.   But I am suggesting full planetary scale snow and ice are not possible because of the warming Sun.  We, as a species, are on the verge of "Climate Control" -- if we do not blow it.

I think more observational data will help quantify the CO2 of the Archean.  For purely emotional reasons, I think the 1000 ppmv is low for CO2; anomolous.  Harder science can swing my fickle emotions, however.

At the very beginings of our universe's creation, there was not only all the mass of a previous star condensed into a small space; rather, the entire mass of the entire universe was compacted into a relatively even smaller space in terms of the densities required to contain the matter. thread.title: Murder or an Accident? The Brain Knows - ScienceNOW

message:
One problem that I see here working with people with Asperger's is that, judging from my own and others experiences, people tend to assume that we can't understand people's motives, when the truth of the matter is that we typically can easily envision a multitude of reasons why a person would act in certain ways, we also recognize that nonverbal communication is hopelessly inaccurate, and so, rather than just prescribe a motive based on multiple plausible possibilities with little reason to pick one over another, we say I don't know, which is the only factual response one can really make.
I am constantly amazed that with the huge literature on common, everyday mistakes on verbal and nonverbal communication, so many people still claim to understand what the people around them are supposedly communicating. If people stopped assuming they understood and spent more time asking for clarification, the world would be a better place.  
I applaud the research and am interested in what they find in future research, I just hope the researchers don't let preconceptions and assumptions about what Aspies or any other group are actually thinking color their interpretations.

thread.title: news.sciencemag.org/scienceinsider/2010/03/elsevier-to-editor-change-contro.html comments

message: The 1988 exchange was only a fledgling first round debate and Science canceled the other rounds after Blattner, Gallo, and Temin lost round 1 so decisively.  Their primary evidence was epidemiological correlations instead of microbiological, and since correlations cannot imply causation, and strong microbiological evidence must be available against HIV prior to it's inclusion in the 1985 AIDS definition, the definition's required match between the hypothetical cause HIV and AIDS were artifactualy generating most of the correlations, so argumenjts of B, G, T looked very weak.  The reason that so much dissent or rethinking exists is because there has still not been a review of the literature that presents strong microbiological evidence against HIV, for example.  So whether it's 1988, 1998 or 2010, debate is still justified until that vital evidence is produced because the Emperor still is without clothes.  Also, without that evidence, using the term denialist 'begs the question' in circular fashion because the very premise that justifies the term (strong evidence exists against HIV) is merely assumed while the term is used to avoid presenting evidence to verify the premise.  So the claim that many people are dead because of AIDS denialism is an additional dimension of begging the question, because again, the evidence that HIV causes AIDS must be produced to make the claim. That's what this is all about. Chigwedere et al also beg the question with their computer model, that's set up on the very assumptions in question, then the flawed model produces numbers that are being used to reinforce the concept 'denialism'  and justify imprisonment of those who dissent...another tautology.  US National Library of Medicine rejected the petition by the 'complaining 18' to delist Medical Hypotheses because their argument about peer review was spurious.  The phrase you use, "fanatical zeal to support authority even when that authority exists to extinguish a people", could just as easily be applied to the AIDS establishment if AIDS drugs are really hurting patients instead of helping, which is a point that dissenters make, and therefore crucial to discuss until those that work for the AIDS establishment can adequately resolve data descrepancies that indicate the drugs harm more than help long term.  Elsevier as owner of course has the right to do what it wants with MH, but it brings into question whether owners of journals should be held to a higher criteria than merely looking at the bottom line, because the history of science strongly suggests that because peer review has many flaws, which include it being used by those of the dominant view, including by knowledge monopolies and research cartels, to hold on to the primary funding sources and hence power.   The fears are understandable, especially as fanned by those in the AIDS establishment, but this is supposed to be the process of science, not a religion although the 'complaining 18' seem to be doing there best to force conversion and baptism.

thread.title: ScienceShot: Translating a Dog's Growl - ScienceNOW

message: Good question - dogs do not distinguish words in human language per se. They are reinforced (via some form of reward or punishment) to associate a particular sound with a particular effect (i.e., "bad" = about to be hit with newspaper, "good" = treat coming my way). The word itself has no inherent meaning to the dog, as you could just as easily train it to associate "bad" with a reward and "good" with a punishment. It is quite a different story if a dog can actually produce different sounds to convey different messages to another member of their species. Of course, this ability might have been learned by the dog at some point in the same way as they "learned" the meaning of "bad", but the fact that they actually produce the sound, rather than merely respond to it, is what is important here.

thread.title: Fish May Not Have Evolved Gills to Breathe - ScienceNOW

message: The research clearly deals with fresh-water fish. In marine fish the major problem is excess water entering the body through the gills. The fact that in the larvae of rainbow trout ion uptake by the gills initially prevails on oxigen uptake does not surprise me: arguably the need for a specialized respiratory organ decreases with animal sizes, whereas ion balance becomes particularly critical (especially in fresh water). The gills of fish are a modification of the pharingeal basket of tunicates, an organ specialized in filtration (for feeding in marine habitats). Overall, I can't see the importance of the results.

thread.title: news.sciencemag.org/scienceinsider/2010/03/elsevier-to-editor-change-contro.html comments

message:
It’s a misleading insinuation that a journal has a peer review problem because they accepted a paper rejected by another journal, since this occurs on a regular basis in publishing.  Additionally, Medical Hypotheses had previously published other articles that questioned the HIV-AIDS hypothesis.  Furthermore, many of the complainers of Medical Hypotheses had also petitioned the Library of Medicine to deselect Medical Hypothesis abstracts in MEDLINE/PUBMED because Medical Hypotheses was not peer reviewed, but the petition was rejected reinforcing their complaint as spurious.  Finally, instead of complaining about the journal, the main complainers being ‘scientists’ could have readily published an article as a rejoinder to Duesberg et al to point out any specific “errors or misinterpretations” themselves, rather than waiting for an anonymous panel 8 months later to do it.  Ignoring all these basic facts, Elsevier then turned a blind eye to what in all appearances seems to be the central purpose of the paper that Duesberg et al responded to (Chigwedere, 2008), which was to avenue the elimination of those who criticize the HIV-AIDS hypotheses through the conception of a computer model based upon the very assumptions questioned by critics; a model that generated an estimated number of 330,000 unnecessary AIDS deaths in South Africa, almost 25 times greater than the number of AIDS deaths indicated by the South African Statistics agency.  The paper then implied that government run public health agencies are ‘science authority’, that scientists that disagree or criticize official pronouncements of public health agencies should be punished legally while the lead author Pride Chigwedere, as the co-discoverer of the AIDS drug Lamivudine (a nucleoside analogue) that WHO recommends in combination with other toxic drugs as the first-line antiviral therapy treatment regimen in Zimbabwe and other developing nations, has a potential conflict of interest.
	Elsevier appeared to react merely from fear of losing profits, instigated by political blackmail, not from any regard for a fit process of science.  Subsequently it convened an anonymous panel to obtain the changes the blackmailers wanted, although the panel of 5 reviewers could not conclude that either of the two articles on trial were a “threat to global public health” or were “potentially libelous” (the originally stated concerns by Elsevier).  Meanwhile no one on the panel, not to mention the blackmailers, seems to be aware that the idealistic reputation of peer review has been effectively challenged, if not damaged, in recent years.  Richard Smith the editor of the British Medical Journal, for example, noted in 2002 that “Refereeing is expensive, time-consuming, inaccurate, subject to bias or worse, doesn’t catch errors let alone fraud--and there’s no objective evidence that it works better than the independent judgment of a qualified editor”.   Indeed hundreds of studies have endeavored to evaluate the effectiveness of peer review, with no definitive evidence found that it protects integrity, or that it reliably results in better papers being published (The Great Betrayal, Horace Freeland Judson:2004).  Indicative is a review of 135 comparative studies by Jefferson et al (JAMA 287, 5 June: 2784-86), presented at the Fourth International Congress on Peer Review in 2002 that concluded: “Until such research is undertaken, peer review should be regarded as an untested process with uncertain outcomes”!

thread.title: Could Tiny Bubbles Cool the Planet? - ScienceNOW

message:
Micro-bubbles have the potential to: 
Radically disrupt feeding and survival strategies
Disrupt foodwebs
Change nutrient availability
Alter habitats, physically and chemically
Affect the weather and change weather patterns
Alter ocean stratification
Alter and interfere with ecosystem function
...

By changing the oceans' albedo -  using micro-bubbles of air:  changing the amount of heating; changing the amount of light that penetrates (reducing the growth of phytoplankton - positively correlated with light, temperature and nutrient availability); altering the habitat and dynamics of the basis of the ocean foodweb - phytoplankton & zooplankton; changing the stratification of areas of the ocean;  possibly altering circulation patterns; changing the weather patterns, potentially disrupting the mechanisms that bring nutrients from the ocean bottom to the surface, increasing available Oxygen at the surface, and changing nutrient availability; changing ocean chemistry...

If much more light is reflected, the ocean will be darker & cooler, marine flora and fauna  which have evolved to live within certain parameters will be affected as their habitat rapidly changes. Creatures which have adapted using properties of light to create camouflage, or assist in hunting or evasion strategies will be negatively affected. All the seabirds which feed by spotting fish may find hunting difficult. 

While the micro-bubble idea is certainly creative, and might well cool the planet, be easy to turn off, and relatively cheap and easy to produce. I think it has huge potential to cause absolute havoc in ocean ecosystems - (which we still don't have a decent working model for - or even a reasonable approximation).  At a time when we are just beginning to investigate the possibility that our long-founded beliefs are wrong - "that the ocean is so vast and so productive, and phytoplankton being the basis of productivity, there is no possibility that we could seriously damage ocean productivity by long term exploitation and removal of productively useful biomass..."
However, research is starting to appear which suggests that over-exploitation may indeed lead to an impoverished, nutrient poor system, affecting species which are not exploited.

When we are still stumbling around in the dark, knowing so little of how the ocean really functions - to implement this sort of idea is criminally irresponsible. There is literally NO way to determine what the impacts will be on ocean eco-systems, because we can't model it in any meaningful way. 

Ok, so we could turn it off - if/when we realize there's a problem. How much more damage can our oceans take and still provide a significant fraction of the world's food supply?

thread.title: No More Black Holes? - ScienceNOW

message: The analogy that time 'stops' at the edge of a 'point of no return' just seems silly.  What can you expect from such a young species in a universe said to be billions of years old?  Just take a look at all the holes in table of elements.  One should note that "reality" concerning the universe as a whole has changed repeatedly since the invention of the telescope.  The old theory of the ball in a spaceship argues that things may move faster than light, provided some sort of device is used to prevent passengers from becoming smudges on the back wall at velocity speeds.  Now I'm just a bit irritated about this whole mess.  First, a small group of folk decide for the rest of us that Pluto is no longer a planet.  Now, black holes don't exist?  Those were a few of my favorite things to read about as a child.  What next, maybe that galaxies are not really collections of stars, but rather rips in space-time looking through a skewed light field at our own juxtaposition in space?  Or perhaps that we are simply billions of tiny motes lost in our understanding of our own ineptitude when it comes to observation of our surroundings.  It's the flat earth theory all over again.  Our understanding of the universe is like a candle to the sun, we have a long way to go before we get there.  Someone develop the warp engine already, then we can zip out there and take a look.

thread.title: No More Black Holes? - ScienceNOW

message: This is an incredibly misleading article, and would people stop using the word infinite to describe the gravity in a black hole? There is a limit (or there is with our science us little fallible beings created) It's just that the escape velocity exceeds that of the (known) fastest thing in the universe, which is light. And simply because the spaceship appears to stop doesn't mean that it did, in reality. Science is based off of observations, so it is true that the spaceship stops to an observer outside of the black holes point of no return, but what about the observers inside of the point of no return? They would still be there, and not stuck in one frame of time (or a quantum second, If remember correctly), so what does this say? Well, it is called the point of no return, which means that once you pass that invisible line the escape velocity of the black hole is too great to be overcome by anything (we think!) in the universe, so you cannot go back, essentially splitting the two observers into places where they can never compare their data, this solves the paradox of appearing to stop, he does stop, yet he doesn't. I'd like to hear you're comments on this, I probably overlooked something!

thread.title: Carl Wieman Chosen for White House Science Post - ScienceInsider

message:
One might have thought that there would have been some mildly critical digging on the part of USA Today, New York Times, Washington Post, or Wall Street Journal on this story. I find Carl Wieman to be well organized, capable of making a good presentation with effective use of information technology, and a persuasive lecturer with a high energy level. 

However, I think that it would be fair to ask Wieman about the following letter from Dr. Marcel Dvorak to the National Post. The President of UBC has refused to comment on this letter. Does what Dvorak wrote reflect in part downstream effects of styles of science teaching and the broken interface between the life sciences and arts subjects such as the teaching of English and the terms of biology and medicine? 

Copyright National Post Company Mar 29, 2008
Re: The Ugly Face Of Medicare, John Turley-Ewart, March 28.
Unfortunately, Jennie's story is not at all unusual in our health care
system. The quality of care she received is directly related to the
lack of capacity at multiple levels within the public health care
system. For a number of years, governments have equated numbers of
physicians and surgeons directly with health care costs and have tried
unsuccessfully to control the latter by restricting the former. The
paradox is that Jennie's life-long disability is likely to be more
costly to society than it would have been to provide adequate surgical
manpower to provide her the timely surgical care and rehabilitation
she required.

I have had the privilege to train over 30 surgeons in a spine
fellowship program at the Vancouver General Hospital and the
University of British Columbia. Out of these, only seven are
practising spine surgery in Canada. As a country, we train enough
surgeons, but we do not have opportunities for them. At the University
of British Columbia we are in the process of doubling our medical
school class size, however, without beds and operating time, we are
simply providing highly trained physicians and surgeons for other
countries.

In the past week or two, I could relate to you stories similar to
Jennie's, but with the diagnoses of misdiagnosed spine fractures,
paralysis due to metastatic cancer to the spine that was undiagnosed
for weeks and gradual paralysis due to spinal stenosis (an easily
treatable degenerative condition).

I am amazed at the lack of public outcry regarding the lack of access
to appropriate care, and I often reflect that if we treated our pet
animals the same way we treat many of our patients, the outcry from
animal rights groups would be deafening.

Dr. Marcel Dvorak, head, Division of Spine, Vancouver Coastal Health
and University of British Columbia.

That is the first question that I would ask Carl: What is your analysis of this Dvorak letter? Do you think that clicking and multiple choice could ameliorate the diagnostic syndromes described by Dvorak? There have been complaints about the overuse of the clicker in biology at UBC. Can we see the evidence, the UBC course evaluations, so that we can assess the effectiveness of clicking for ourselves? 

After the Amy Bishop matter, I thought that the President of the USA would say that to get federal funding all American universities would have to have open performance reviews and course evaluations. Strangely, he did not seem to grasp the issue at all. What is Carl's explanation of the somewhat painful and confused set of practices in relation to course evaluations at UBC? 

The second most important question for Carl is the Regina v. Hwi Lee judgment of Judge R.D. Fratkin April 28, 2009. When I went over to the Richmond courthouse to get the judgment, I found that it was not at all in demand. The Korean student Hwi Lee made threats against biosciences at UBC. He was terrified of making oral presentations. Instead of helping to strengthen high school biology in BC so that such problems would be identified and dealt with far earlier, UBC appeared not to be able to grasp the language issues at all. An indirect reflection perhaps of how Carl tends to devalue language. I was stunned when he told me that language and science are totally separate, so that clearly he would not be able to understand how international students would need enriched English (or French) programs to thrive in science in America or Canada.

UBC has been afflicted for at least a dozen years by professors in the English department teaching their own books instead of adopting some of the most remarkable products of the corpus revolution in linguistics, such as the COBUILD English Grammar and Longman Dictionary of Contemporary English. Carl Wieman gave me the impression that it would be pointless to discuss with him the language factor in science. He apparently can't orient to this issue at all.

Carl, do you have the Hwi Lee judgment? What is your assessment of this judgment? 

It is not only in first-year English that UBC is struggling with chaotic practices. Nor is UBC to blame more than many other universities in that the interface between the arts and sciences is fractured. It is impossible to understand why universities do not construct terms of biology courses, for example, based on first- and second-year biology texts, many of which are superior. Such courses should employ as their models corpus methods in linguistics. Perhaps the AAAS could review all the terms of biology and medicine courses in the USA and Canada and choose the least mechanistic and most powerful. If you can find any such course. 

Therefore, if America had serious education journalists, at least two of the subject areas--Dvorak, Hwi Lee, arts-sciences interface, English for science students--would have been fully explored by now. 

We see today in the papers that national reading skills continue to register as "mediocre." Well, no wonder. If analytical depth in education reporting just does not exist, you cannot expect improvement. 

Clayton Burns PhD Vancouver claytonburns@gmail.com

thread.title: New Report Explains 'Why So Few' Women in Science - ScienceInsider

message:
I'm always surprised how 'unscientific' the analysis of race/gender issues is in science.  For instance, the statement 
"significant numbers of women and underrepresented minority chemists and chemical engineers say they were discouraged from pursuing"
is purely anecdotal.  How do we know that white male chemists and chemical engineers were not similarly discouraged?
The implicit assumption of most of these studies seems to be that there must be some form of discrimination, as 'proven' by the numerical discrepancies.  This is the worst kind of scientific bias.  I'd have more respect for these kinds of studies if they included other possible explanations.
  I also object to the idea that strict numerical parity should be our goal.  There is not a single male teacher at my children's elementary school, yet they are not burdened with task forces, review committees and hiring inquisitions trying to establish gender parity.  When will we grow up enough as a society to accept that peoples choices come primarily from their cultural and personal preferences, not from biases in 'the establishment', even if the results do not reflect our intellectual preconceptions.

thread.title: Internet Pioneer to Chart Web's Next Leap - ScienceInsider

message:
The semantic web is a component of web 3.0, it isn't web 3.0 in it's entirety. 

"People keep asking what Web 3.0 is," Berners-Lee said. "I think maybe when you've got an overlay of scalable vector graphics - everything rippling and folding and looking misty - on Web 2.0 and access to a semantic Web integrated across a huge space of data, you'll have access to an unbelievable data resource."

http://www.nytimes.com/2006/05/23/technology/23iht-web.html

thread.title: /sciencenow/2010/03/playing-fair-came-late.html comments

message:
The argument put forth in the last paragraph could equally be countered by pointing out that members of small tribal societies treat the games as real and anticipate real consequences (such as the risk of offering to cooperate with strangers) whereas college students have a clear idea of the division between the virtual and real worlds and have well adapted and distinct personalities used to navigate the two separate worlds.

Hence an argument could be put forward that people not used to virtual (game) worlds more honestly depict their real behaviour.  It is my understanding that the nearest comparison to game theory behaviour that has been demonstrated is the behaviour of stock market traders, which is renowned as an unreal environment quite unlike the real world and a game that few people can play well (because they can't sufficiently divorce themselves from reality when large amounts of real money is involved.)

message: This concept of a microbial signature, though not entirely unheard of, is truly amazing. The procedure lacks the robustness of DNA finger printing as there are many compounding variables. A change in the habitat due to relocation, change in dietary habits and current health status are some factors that can change the microbial profile of an individual. Focusing on these variables itself can become a topic for future research and teaching.

message: In addition, algal blooms produce isoprene, the next most abundant biologically derived greenhouse-gas  hydrocarbon after methane. Although short-lived, one of its breakdown products is ozone, both toxic and a greenhouse gas itself. Dead aglae reaching th sediment could also be expected to contribute to sediment methane releases. Surface algae decay will release the organic molecules used by a group of aerobic bacteria that, as a by-product of their metabolism, emit methane (study reported last year).
